# 1. Data Import and Cleaning

## 1.1 Data Import

```{r echo=TRUE, eval=TRUE}
mydata <- read.csv("Fake Data DOE_IV 1_24_2017.csv", header = TRUE, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
```

## 1.2 Data Preprocessing

Define a few lists of variables of interests for further use:

```{r}
# Categorical and numerical variables
independent.variables.cat <- c("Surface.Preparation", "Contaminate.Type")
independent.variables.num <- c("Adhesive.Out.Time", "Prep..to.Bond.Time", "Contamination.Amount")
# All 5 variables
independent.variables.all <- c(independent.variables.cat, independent.variables.num)
```

Use `str()` and `summary()` to look at variable types and summary statistics; use `head()` or `tail()` to take a peep at the data.

```{r eval=FALSE, tidy=TRUE}
str(mydata[c("Adhesive.Out.Time", "Prep..to.Bond.Time", "Contamination.Amount", "Surface.Preperation", "Contaminate.Type", "Gic")])
summary(mydata[c("Adhesive.Out.Time", "Prep..to.Bond.Time", "Contamination.Amount", "Surface.Preperation", "Contaminate.Type", "Gic")])
head(mydata[, c("Adhesive.Out.Time", "Prep..to.Bond.Time", "Contamination.Amount", "Surface.Preperation", "Contaminate.Type", "Gic")])
tail(mydata[, c("Adhesive.Out.Time", "Prep..to.Bond.Time", "Contamination.Amount", "Surface.Preperation", "Contaminate.Type", "Gic")])
```

Based on our immediate observation, we will

  * impose correct data types to all interested variables, 
  * create a new factor *y* representing *Gic* as *High* and *Low*,
  * omit NA's, and 
  * fix weird NEGATIVE values observed in Prep..to.Bond.Time
  
```{r warning=FALSE}
# Correct data types
mydata$Adhesive.Out.Time <- as.numeric(mydata$Adhesive.Out.Time)
mydata$Prep..to.Bond.Time <- as.numeric(mydata$Prep..to.Bond.Time)
mydata$Surface.Preperation <- as.factor(mydata$Surface.Preperation)
mydata$Contaminate.Type <- as.factor(mydata$Contaminate.Type)
mydata$Contamination.Amount <- as.numeric(mydata$Contamination.Amount)
# Gic -> y = 'LowGic' or 'HighGic'
mydata$y <- as.factor(ifelse(mydata$Gic < 5, 'LowGic', 'HighGic'))
# Omit NA's
mydata <- na.omit(mydata)
# (*) FIX weird negative values observed in Prep..to.Bond.Time
mydata$Prep..to.Bond.Time <- abs(mydata$Prep..to.Bond.Time)
# Add a duplicate column of Surface.Preperation with correct column name
mydata$Surface.Preparation <- mydata$Surface.Preperation
```

```{r echo=FALSE, out.width="8\\linewidth"}
#
ggplot(mydata) + geom_violin(aes(x = Surface.Preparation, y = Gic, fill = Surface.Preparation)) + facet_wrap(~ Contaminate.Type) + ggtitle("Surface Preparation vs Gic, by Contaminate Type")

```
#### Workflow Summary:
1) Barplot on one categorical variable
2) Represent how each bar is made up by another variable
    - second variable is factor: add fill color in barplot
    - second variable is numerical: as the y-axis in violin plot
3) Make multiple facets by a 3rd (even a 4th, if it makes sense yet still tidy) variable (factor)

# 3. Classifying *Gic* with Support Vector Machine
#
#
## 3.1 Construction patterns of the experimental data
#
The experiment is so designed that for each combination of **Surface Preparation** and **Contaminate Type**, 12 experiments (in most of cases except for "Fre" or something) are conducted with variations in other 3 numerical variables. It is observable from the data that for each 12 experiments sharing the same **Surface Preparation** and **Contaminate Type**, 6 of them always have a higher **Contamination Amount** while the other 6 have a lower value. Let's visualize this observation.

```{r results='hide'}
library(caret)
library(kernlab)
```

#### Training

```{r echo=FALSE}
# Construct training and testing subsets
set.seed(8341)
samp <- sample(nrow(mydata), 0.6 * nrow(mydata))
mydata.train <- mydata[samp, c(independent.variables.all, "y")]
mydata.test <- mydata[-samp, c(independent.variables.all, "y")]
#
svm.model <- ksvm(y ~ ., data = mydata.train)
print(svm.model)
# plot(svm.model, data = mydata.train)
```

#### Prediction

```{r echo=FALSE}
svm.pred <- predict(svm.model, mydata.test)
table(svm.pred, mydata.test$y)
confusionMatrix(svm.pred, mydata.test$y)
```

#### Error from cross-validation
```{r echo=FALSE}
svm.model <- ksvm(y ~ ., data = rbind(mydata.train, mydata.test), cross=50)
print(svm.model)
# plot(svm.model, data = mydata.train)
```
